title: 114_hr3985
content: The Act may be cited as the "Jumpstart Our Businesses by Supporting Students Act of 2015" or the "JOBS Act of 2015". Job training Federal Pell Grants are addressed in the Act. Section 401 of the Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended to include a Job Training Federal Pell Grant Program starting in the 2016-2017 award year. Eligible students must not have attained a baccalaureate or postbaccalaureate degree. The Job Training Federal Pell Grant Program, starting in the 2016-2017 award year, is for eligible students who have not attained a baccalaureate or postbaccalaureate degree. Students must be enrolled in a job training program at an institution of higher education and meet all other Federal Pell Grant eligibility requirements. The grant amount is determined under subsection (b)(2)(A), with a maximum award for an award year. The Job Training Federal Pell Grant Program awards 50% of the maximum Federal Pell Grant for the award year. No increase is calculated for students receiving this grant, and certain regulations do not apply. The period during which a student receives this grant counts towards their total eligibility period for Federal Pell Grants. In subsection (c), regulations for students in undergraduate programs on less than full-time basis also apply to students in job training programs at eligible institutions. Definitions in this subsection include "eligible career pathways program" aligning with skill needs. The curr_chunk discusses services that align with industry skill needs, prepare individuals for various education options including apprenticeships, provide counseling for education and career goals, and offer concurrent education. The curr_chunk outlines the requirements for education and training programs to align with workforce preparation activities, accelerate career advancement, achieve educational milestones, and facilitate entry or advancement in specific occupations. The curr_chunk defines a job training program as a career and technical education program at a higher education institution that provides at least 150 hours of instruction over 8 weeks, aligned with employer requirements in the state or local area. The curr_chunk outlines criteria for a job training program, including providing a recognized postsecondary credential and meeting academic content requirements. The job training program must meet hiring requirements, allow students to apply for licenses, may include basic skills courses, and be part of a career pathways program.
